msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This compact Book of Hours opens with a calendar containing Saints associated with Flanders and Northern France, including Saints Amandus and Vedastus (February 6, fol. 2r), Saints Remigius and Bavo (October 1, fol. 10r), Saint Eligius (December 1, fol. 12r) and Saint Nicasius (December 14, fol. 12r). Following the calendar, the book contains the Hours of the Cross and the Hours of the Holy Spirit, followed by the Mass of the Virgin, the Hours of the Virgin for the Use of Rome, and the Advent Hours of the Virgin. The Penitential Psalms, Litany, and Prayers are followed by the Office of the Dead. The final sections contain the Obsecro te and O intemerata prayers, the Psalter of Saint Jerome, a Suffrage to Saint Sebastian, and a Mass of the Archangel Raphael for those who travel. A coat-of-arms (azure a siband sinister or, over all a lion rampant sable to sinister), likely belonging to the original owner, is found on fol. 13r. The manuscript contains seventeen full-page miniatures with blank versos, added as singletons but original to the book. Three miniatures were illuminated in the workshop of the Bruges illuminator Guillaume (William) Vrelant (fl. 1449-1481). Vrelant is considered one of the most influential illuminators active in Bruges during the third quarter of the fifteenth century.

msItem.title: Book of Hours, use of Rome
Hours of the Virgin, Use of Rome
Large miniature, Coronation of the Virgin
Hours of the Virgin for Advent
Large miniature, King David in Prayer
Prayers to the Virgin, Obsecro te and O intemerata

supportDesc.extent: iii+262+iii; 97 x 70 mm bound to 104 x 77 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.signatures: Cropped horizontal catchwords partially visible at folios: 21v, 39v, 128v, 162v, 179v

layoutDesc.layout: One column of fifteen lines, ruled in faint red ink; written area: 53 x 36 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Seventeen full-page miniatures: Crucifixion (fol. 13v), Pentecost (fol. 22v), Virgin and Child Enthroned (fol. 30v), Annunciation (fol. 45v), Visitation (fol. 69v), Nativity (fol. 83v), Annunciation to the Shepherds (fol. 90v), Adoration of the Magi (fol. 96v), Presentation in the Temple (fol. 102v), Massacre of the Innocents (fol. 108v), Flight into Egypt (fol. 118v), Coronation of the Virgin (fol. 126v), David in Prayer (fol. 138v), Office of the Dead (fol. 163v), Saint Jerome (fol. 226v), Martyrdom of Saint Sebastian (fol. 251v), Archangel Raphael Guiding Tobias (fol. 254v); seventeen five-to-six-line illuminated initials, two-line illuminated initials with foliate sprays and one-line illuminated initials throughout, thirty-four full foliate borders enclosing miniatures and facing text, some inhabited
[Flyleaf 1 verso]Bookplate with page and volume count
[Flyleaf 2 recto]Bookplate, Clarence H. Clark with J.F. Lewis stamp
13vMarginal figure, Angel with instruments of the passion

binding.p: Early nineteenth century, English straight-grained black morocco, gold and blind-tooled and stamped with Masonic symbols, spine labeled in gold: "OFFIC. B.M.V."

origin.p: Unidentified coat-of-arms (azure a siband sinister or, over all a lion rampant sable to sinister), apparently original, on fol. 13r; 1460s

history.provenance: Clarence H. Clark (sale, Philadelphia, 1909, I, no. 182); John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936; On the second front flyleaf, a note is pasted in: "Sale of Clarence H. Clark, no. 182." The description of this item for sale is pasted onto the reverse; Unidentified coat of arms – a blue shield with silver lion rampant and gold diagonal – appears on the bottom of fol. 14r
